answers.answer: not necessarily.  the most common reason that I see in clinic is "inappropriate sinus tachycardia" which essentially means that your heart rate is faster than it should be based on your level of exertion.  I see several cases of this per week.  If other causes are ruled out with a echocardiogram and normal thyroid studies and a good history/physical, that is the most likely diagnosis.  The treatment is usually beta blockers or calcium channel blockers and reassurance that your heart is ok --- anxiety can play role in making it worse but does not explain everything about it.  Is it a risk factor for cardiovascular events over the long term -- yes it is, but it is not one of the big risk factors like hypertension, diabetes, increased cholesterol, family history or tobacco.  It is only a piece of the puzzle.  You manage your risk of disease every day with decisions that you don't think about like do I exercise or have these French fries instead.  These are controllable significant choices.  Your heart rate, if you do in fact have inappropriate sinus tachycardia, is not as easy to control.  My philosophy is to focus on controllable factors because you can change them.  Worrying about things beyond your control is just worrying.I hope this addresses your questions and eases your concerns rather than increase them --- I was trying to decrease your concerns and hope that it came across that way.
